posts.name: Micah Doberne-Schor
posts.cooked: Hi CD , There is starting to be some discussion in our team for what to do next with swerve. The past 2 seasons, we have used REV maxswerve modules with normal neos as the drive motors (we have played around with gear ratio upgrade kits). But we still feel like neos/maxswerve is starting to hold us back (and neo550s burning up and destroying sparkmaxes is definitely annoying). We are considering changing both our motor and our module type. However, while we do have some funds to spend, we want to be cautious to not break the bank. In your experience, what has been the optimal motor and swerve module paring for both speed and acceleration

posts.name: Ainesh Yarlagadda
posts.cooked: This is going to break the bank, but mk4i krakens I think

posts.name: Goli
posts.cooked:
Can you tell me how you’re burning up your sparkmax controllers?

We used maxSwerve for the first time this year and have had no issues with it at all. We are using NEOs and neo550’s as well.

Trust me, nobody is at the point where they are limited by using MaxSwerve.  I’d be curious as to how you arrived at this conclusion that you need different swerve motors/modules.

posts.name: Ainesh Yarlagadda
posts.cooked: Also, are you having problems running out of wheels? I know this might not be a problem now, but I remember it happening at worlds so much that a team asked us not to pick them because they had run out of swerve wheels

posts.name: JAMES
posts.cooked:
mk4is with kraken drive and neo turn are amazing.

Expensive but for sure worth the cost.

posts.name: Stewart Riley
posts.cooked: We’ve had great success with WCP Swerve X (and now X2) modules. The last two iterations of these we’ve powered with Kraken motors. This season we had an extremely reliable and fast swerve drive using Swerve X2t modules with Kraken X60s for drive motors and Kraken X44s for turn motors. The extra-wide TPU tread of the X2 modules has been especially nice.

The most common types of swerve mechanisms used by teams (I believe) are the WCP Swerve X series and SDS ’s MK4 Series. The main difference between these two types is how the turning mechanisms are powered. The MK4 Series uses a belt, while the Swerve X Series uses a gear. Additionally, WCP ’s Swerve products are slightly more affordable compared to SDS ’s.

I believe that sticking to the CTRE family of products would be the most beneficial, as Tuner X can generate swerve code for you, which would save a significant amount of time and maintenance effort. The power of the Kraken motor would ensure high acceleration and speed.

Our team has been using the Full Kraken MK4i L3 this year, and it worked out just fine.

If you were to switch modules I would go with a WCP . But I think you might want to reconsider. We had some trouble with our MAXSwerve last year but this year, after taking them apart, cleaning them, and maintaining our modules better, they have behaved very well. Your NEO 550s shouldn’t burn up if you set a reasonable current limit (they don’t really need more than 20 A). With the MAXSwerve V1.1 upgrade key issues are mostly eliminated as well. If you want you can put Krakens on your MAXSwerve;  but I don’t think you really need to switch module type (unless you really want all CTRE ; even then you can run your 550s off an FXS).

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: We used the same thing in 2024 and we didn’t experience any issues. For 2025, we chose to upgrade to Vortexes for the drive motors, keeping 550s for turning. This gives us more power, and we’ve found our swerve to be more or less on the same level as other teams with MK4s or SwerveX.

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked:
While there are definitely downsides to the Max swerves you should not be burning motors or motor controllers with them, there is something deeper going on.  If you’re burning 550s its usually a current limit issue. If you’re concerned about speed, the extra gear ratios take care of that, and you can buy the aluminum wheels and cut or print your own tread like every other module. The Rev modules and motors can definitely be reliable if used with some care. You need current limits and the ultra planetaries are extremely sensitive to overtightening. When we were on Max Swerve we intentionally removed certain screws because they were hard to check and could wreck the modules if they loosened up too much. But with those considerations, we had basically no issues for our 2024 robot.

That said this year we’re using Thrifty modules and have been quite happy with them. They’ve been extremely reliable except for a bearing issue that was fixed with revised top plates. Thrifty was in the pits at MSC with replacement parts helping teams repair the modules, so great customer service albeit for a issue I really wish had been caught earlier. We’ve done almost no maintenance and with a bit of cleaning I think they’d look basically new. Very happy with the modules and that we don’t have to deal with the Ultra planetaries any more.

posts.name: Micah Doberne-Schor
posts.cooked: so for the wheels, we were using plastic wheels, mainly for ease of use. We monitored their wear and tear during an offseason competition, and were therefore able to determine how many wheels to bring.

posts.name: Micah Doberne-Schor
posts.cooked: Our neo 550 was only on a 20 amp breaker, so its not electrical. It just very occasionally smokes and dies. It happened to several other teams that I know as well when they ran max swerve.

Check your current limits. These should not be more than 60A for NEO and 20A for NEO550. If this is not set, your motors will overheat and short in the data cable. If you connect a burned motor to a SparkMAX there is a possibility that this short will destroy the SparkMAX.

Try to resolve these issues before investing in new equipment even if it is just to prevent the same issues with your new swerve.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
BouncingBuilder:

Our neo 550 was only on a 20 amp breaker, so its not electrical.

A 20A breaker will allow a heap more than 20A for a certain amount of time.  The REV breakers seem to have a particularly generous rating in this regard, but same goes for the Snap Action breakers too.  Current limiting at the motor controller is where it’s at.

four:

If you connect a burned motor to a SparkMAX there is a possibility that this short will destroy the SparkMAX.

I’ve seen and heard of this happening with smoked NEO 1.x motors, but not the 550.  Do you have data points to the contrary?

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Can you double check that you’re not accidentally resetting the sparkmax to brushed mode at some point?

posts.name: Mert Ata BABER
posts.cooked: We plan to switch our MK4i’s drive motors from NEO to Kraken and continue using the NEO for the turn. Have you experienced any issues with this setup?

posts.name: Michael Havrylyuk
posts.cooked:
We had a burned-out neo 550 destroy a Spark Max (wasn’t on swerve). definitely possible and probably what happened to the OP. OP needs to check with programming team and make sure the current limit is being set in code at about 20A. The default on spark maxes is 80A, which will definitely burn out a neo 550 in a few seconds if the wheel ever gets stuck or has slightly too much friction.

To OP: Dont buy new swerve modules. They cost a lot. Maxswerve with the spikey wheels that rev sells have been amazing for us. We only had to replace the wheels after quals and they still had some life in them when we did. If you arent already running the spikey wheels please try them.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: The spiky wheels are amazing, we ran them for the entirety of our regional and they’ve still got plenty of life left in them.

posts.name: JAMES
posts.cooked:
We ran this configuration for the whole on and off season this year and I can happily say that we had a record low amount of swerve issues (just an encoder screw that had nothing to do with the motor.)

I don’t code myself but my code team didn’t seem to have any issues either.

My team has been using SDS mk4i with kraken x60s to a lot of sucess. However, if I were to start again, I think would chose to use the WCP X2s line of modules. I really like the concept of molded wheels, and the modules as a whole are a bit less expensive than other modules. I would also strongly suggest going with CTRE motors, as they are so much easier to work with than Neos and Neo 550s and are SO MUCH more reliable and issue-free.
